p: The viral capsid is composed of 180 copies (90 dimers) of VP1, which consists of a shell (S) domain and two protruding (P1 and P2) domains [ 33]. The P2 domain extends above the viral surface and represents the most diverse region of the genome. The P2 domain is responsible for binding to histo-blood group antigens (HBGAs), which function as receptors or co-receptors on host cells [ 34], and it contains important determinants of antigenicity. Viral particles contain only a few copies of VP2, which are associated with the interior surface of the capsid formed by the S domain of VP1 [ 35, 36].
